comments.body:
if `NonBlockingRun` returns an `error` we won't:
- stop the AuditBacked
- stop the `goroutine 1`
- stop the `goroutine 2`

we are aborting, the primary goroutine that is executing `Run` will abort and all other go routines will be aborted with it. I don't think we need to be graceful when `Run` returns an error, thoughts?
okay, I moved `s.AuditBackend.Run` to its original site, now it is in keeping with the current implementation
should we convert to structured logging?
`[graceful-termination]` is just a prefix so we can search all graceful termination related log entries with this keyword. Is there a way to add a prefix in structured logging?

I don't understand this change.

We wait for delayedStopCh 4 lines above. So the new goroutine you introduced doesn't add any new synchronization.

Can you explain?

@wojtek-t  so this is the sequence of events:
- `A`:  T+0s: we receive `KILL` signal (`stopCh` is signaled)
- `B`: T+70s: `ShutdownDelayDuration` elapses, (`delayedStopCh` is signaled)
- `C`: T+70s: as soon as `ShutdownDelayDuration` elapses we should signal `WithWaitGroup` that it should send `5xx` with a `Retry-After` response header.
- `D`: wait for existing requests in flight to drain
- `E`: The `server.Shutdown` returns (`stoppedCh` is signaled)

So currently `C` happens after `E`, the new goroutine in this PR ensures that `C` happens immediately after `B`. 

> We wait for delayedStopCh 4 lines above.

yes, we don't really need that any longer, it can be simplified as shown below:
```
<-drainedCh
<-stoppedCh
```

OK - that makes sense.

Please update this part to what you wrote above then.

done, thanks!

also, as an FYI, I have a WIP PR https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/101257 that makes an attempt at:
- refactors the graceful termination logic and adds unit test so we can verify the expected behavior. 
- add a new mode of graceful termination to keep listening until the existing requests in flight drain

I am going to split it to two separate PRs - one with the refactor only and the other with new mode, I will ping you when it is ready for review.
I've briefly skimmed that some time ago - splitting out refactoring part to a separate PR is a good thing to do.
This is probably not ideal, we should probably silently fail. Should we still record the error somewhere?
So we are failing somewhere because of that for CRDs. If this is about a built-in type, we should clearly not fail silently.
ack, fixed.
maybe another comment?
done.

somewhat of a pre-existing issue (since PostStartHooks()/PreShutdownHooks() return unexported types), but declaring an interface method with an unexported return type makes it really hard for other interface implementers.
optional nit: we're up to five fields for health checks at this point, three are the same as readiness.  I would consider a struct.
That sounds like a good idea. I'll refactor this in a follow-up PR.

comments.body: do we want to log that we're waiting for requests to complete here? do we want to set a time limit on how long we'll wait?
The shutdown of the server has a context already with the timeout. Following the api docs, we don't need another timeout here.
ok
note to self: this file shows a big diff that I didn't carefully review. (yet?)

We are changing the permissions necessary for create-on-update; we need a big release note for this. I think it is a good change, it means patch/put never implies create--formerly sometimes it did in a hard to reason about way. But administrators will need to know. Can you add to the feature branch change log file I started so we don't forget?
This PR is to master, since it is just affecting create on update, which is broken in master. Should I remake this to the feature branch?

After moving everything over to our own WaitGroup (which looks all good btw code-wise!), one question from a few steps back:

The internalStopCh is eventually passed down to `RunServer`. `RunServer` will shutdown the http server below: `server.Shutdown()`. After the http server is down, no **new** request is going to be processed.

Q: does `server.Shutdown()` enforce that all request handlers have been returned?

About the race we saw in CI: the `s.HandlerChainWaitGroup.Wait()` here is potentially called before `server.Shutdown()` has returned. So even if the upper question is answered with 'yes', the `Wait` is called before the last `waitGroup.Add`. This is the race we saw (and this race is fixed with our own WaitGroup now).

Now my concern:

In the situation of the race we saw (i.e. Add after Wait at counter==0), this `s.HandlerChainWaitGroup.Wait()` with our new WaitGroup will return early before the last request has been processed. Is this true? If yes, we loose events, don't we?

In other words: I have the suspicion that the occurance of the detected race (with the old WaitGroup) means that we loose events now (with the new WaitGroup).

>Q: does server.Shutdown() enforce that all request handlers have been returned?

For all the connections, Shutdown will wait until they turn into idle state,  then close them.  If a connection always stay active, Shutdown will close it until timeout.

>In other words: I have the suspicion that the occurance of the detected race (with the old WaitGroup) means that we loose events now (with the new WaitGroup).

In theory, events lost can exist. And it is with very low probability.

@@ -1,1 +326,330 @@		<-stopCh
		close(internalStopCh)
		s.HandlerChainWaitGroup.Wait()
		close(auditStopCh)
	}()

comments.body: can the audit shutdown be a pre stop hook as well?
/cc @hzxuzhonghu @crassirostris
Yes, audit backend can register a prestop/poststop hook too.
I think we should even have a synchronization of closing the listener and calling the hooks here.

This of course means that some API server clients in an HA setup might get a connection refused. On the other hand, we cannot make kube-proxy updates synchronous anyway. So it does not matter much for external clients which order we have here.

But, auditing needs this synchronization.
You mean do not call the shutdown hooks until the listener is closed?
Yes, but I am fine with wiring this in a follow-up. We definitely need that for auditing.

Just realized: this changes the shutdown behaviour of every apiserver. We now wait for running requests to finish. This can take up to 60sec. I think it's the right behaviour, but we at least have to document that in the release notes. Wondering whether we also have make this configurable, either via Config and/or flag.

@deads2k ^^
@hzxuzhonghu I update the changelog in this direction. Can you prove-read that it is correct?
Sure

comments.body: @deads2k did you expect this to be exported or not?

The generic API server repo is for supporting the common case for a "normal" API server.  No normal API server will need this update power, so this should not be on the struct here. 

The aggregator can have its own special endpoint to avoid muddying the "easy path" implementation.
Do we use a normal API server code path for serving Custom Resources? I heard something about those resources can have dynamic OpenAPI spec, right?

More on this from another comment by @sttts:

> Static in which sense? Resources can come and go. With CRD validation, we will also get JSON Schema snippets that can change any moment and should be part of the OpenAPI spec served by the aggregator.

I think not only we need this, we need an upstream channel to tell aggregator it changed (maybe something like a watch on OpenAPI spec).
Watchable discovery, https://github.com/kubernetes/community/pull/617

That could work for OpenAPI spec, though I assume you can modify schema for a custom resource without adding/removing the APIService, right? In that case we may need a separate watch for OpenAPI spec (or modify discovery watch to support it)
Or add the schema somehow to discovery, e.g. with a hash.

This doesn't look right.  In the general case of openapi aggregation you don't have this level of access and given the unprotected handler chain from the delegate, this extra side-bar of communication shouldn't be necessary.
Do you mean I can call http serve method of delegate to get `/swagger.spec` without credentials?
empty line below, none above.
Will fix.
